column4: hello, how can I set a kernel set (low-latency) to boot every time in grub?
in /boot/grub/menu.lst set "default <number of your conf>" iirc
but what about kernel updates?
yes you would have to modify that but isn't that the whole point of manually setting a specific kernel?
I'm not specifying a manual kernel
it's a kernel installed through ubuntu, it's the kernel-low-latency package, which automatically installs the latest low-latency kernel.  Right now it's defaulting to the normal -i386 one though.
can you paste your grub config somewhere? don't have one handy but i think ubuntu uses savedefault so it will use the last kernel booted upon reboot
sorry about that:  here is my menu.lst if you are still available.  http://pastebin.ca/549329
change "default 0" on line 14 to "default saved" that way you will always boot the last used kernel
which makes sense in your case since you have to reboot on kernel updates anyway and this boot on subsequent reboots always the newest one
not newest but just the last used one, it's up to you to at least one time choose the right one in the menu
i'm not aware of more automation than that...
normally whenever a new kernel is installed, ubuntu automatically boots that one, always has.
thanks, I'll give this a try.
that's because other kernels are appended to the end of the config by debcons and "default 0" says boot the first kernel in the list i think "default saved" is the closest you can get
but ubuntu is automatically adding the kernels in menu.lst
yup i just think it's adding them at the end of the config, and "default 0" which is now there says "boot the first one"
lol, why would it add at the end?
guess programmatically it's easier to just append to a file. maybe someone was lazy (but i'm just guessing here i didn't care about that as i use custom kernels)
I see; maybe it's just a bug in the -low-latency kernel or something.
no it's not adding it to the end, it's just adding it under the i-386 one.
